title: A note of caution about recent AI risk coverage — EA Forum
author: Unknown Author
content:
_Epistemic status: some thoughts I wanted to get out quickly_

A lot of fantastic work has been done by people in the AI existential risk research community and related communities over the last several months in raising awareness about risks from advanced AI. However, I have some cause for unease that I’d like to share.

These efforts may have been too successful too soon.

Or, more specifically, this level of outreach success this far ahead of the development of AI capable of posing existential risk may have fallout. We should consider steps to mitigate this. 

**(1)**  **Timelines**

I know that there are well-informed people in the AI and existential risk communities who believe AI capable of posing existential risk may be developed within 10 years. I certainly can’t rule this out, and even a small chance of this is worth working to prevent or mitigate to the extent possible, given the possible consequences. My own timelines are longer, although my intuitions don’t have a rigorous model underpinning them (my intuitions line up similarly to the 15-40 year timelines mentioned in [this recent blog post](https://epochai.org/blog/a-compute-based-framework-for-thinking-about-the-future-of-ai) by Matthew Barnett from Epoch).

Right now the nature of media communications means that the message is coming across with a lot of urgency. From speaking to lay colleagues, impressions often seem to be of short timelines (and some folks e.g. Geoff Hinton have explicitly said 5-20 years, sometimes with uncertainty caveats and sometimes without).

It may be that those with short (<10 years) timelines are right. And even if they’re not, and we’ve got decades before this technology poses an existential threat, many of the attendant challenges – alignment, governance, distribution of benefits – will need that additional time to be addressed. And I think it’s entirely plausible that the current level of buy-in will be needed in order to initiate the steps needed to avoid the worst outcomes, e.g. recruiting expertise and resources to alignment, development and commitment to robust regulation, even coming to agreements not to pursue certain technological developments beyond a certain point.

 However, if short timelines do not transpire, I believe there’s a need to consider a scenario I think is reasonably likely.

**(2)**  **Crying wolf**

I propose that it is most likely we are in a world where timelines are >10 years, perhaps >20 or 30 years. Right now this issue has a lot of the most prominent AI scientists and CEOs signed up, and political leaders worldwide committing to examining the issue seriously ([examples](https://twitter.com/RishiSunak/status/1663838958558539776;) [from](https://theelders.org/news/elders-urge-global-co-operation-manage-risks-and-share-benefits-ai;) [last](https:// https://twitter.com/tedlieu/status/1664430739717255168) week). What happens then in the >10 year-timeline world?

 The extinction-level outcomes that the public is hearing, and that these experts are raising and policymakers making costly reputational investments in, don’t transpire.  What does happen is all the benefits of near-term AI that have been talked about, plus all the near-term harms that are being predominantly raised by the AI ethics/FAccT communities. Perhaps these harms include somewhat more extreme versions than what is currently talked about, but nowhere near catastrophic. Suddenly the year is 2028, and that whole 2023 furore is starting to look a bit silly. Remember when everyone agreed AI was going to make us all extinct? Yeah, like Limits to Growth all over again. Except that we’re not safe. In reality, in this scenario, we’re just entering the period in which risk is most acute, and in which gaining or maintaining the support of leaders across society for coordinated action is most important. And it’s possibly even harder to convince them, because people remember how silly lots of people looked the last time. [\[1\]](#fnkcq5okqj3r)  [\[2\]](#fngk9hef3oa5)

**(3)**  **How to navigate this scenario (in advance).** 

Suggestions:

*   Have our messaging make clear that we don’t know when extinction-potential AI will be developed, and it’s quite likely that it will be over a decade, perhaps much longer. But it needs to be discussed now, because
    *   we can’t rule out that it will be developed sooner;
    *   there are choices to be made now that will have longer-term consequences;
    *   the challenges need a lot more dedicated time and effort than they’ve been getting.  
          
        Uncertainty is difficult to communicate in media, but it’s important to try.
*   [Don’t be triumphal](https://twitter.com/yonashav/status/1664505416846376960) over winning the public debate now; it may well be ‘lost’ again in 5 years
*   Don’t unnecessarily antagonise the AI ethics/FaCCT folk [\[3\]](#fnmxdrl9nlph) because they’re quite likely to look like the ones who were right in 5 years (and because it’s just unhelpful).
*   Build bridges where possible with the AI ethics/FaCCT folk on a range of issues and interventions that seem set to overlap in that time; work together where possible. Lots of people from those communities are making proposals that are relevant and overlapping with challenges associated with the path to transformative AI. This includes external evaluation; licensing and liability; oversight of powerful tech companies developing frontier AI; international bodies for governing powerful AI, and much more. E.g. see [this](https://ainowinstitute.org/publication/gpai-is-high-risk-should-not-be-excluded-from-eu-ai-act) and [this](https://www.wired.com/story/ai-desperately-needs-global-oversight/), as well as [CAIS's recent blog post.](https://www.safe.ai/post/three-policy-proposals-for-ai-safety)
*   Don’t get fooled into thinking everyone now agrees. A lot more senior names are now signing onto statements and speaking up, and this is making it easier for previously silent-but-concerned researchers to speak up. However I think a majority of AI researchers probably still don’t agree this is a serious, imminent concern ([Yann LeCun’s silent majority](https://twitter.com/ylecun/status/1664011158989275138) is probably still real), and this disconnect in perceptions may result in significant pushback to come.
*   Think carefully about the potential political fallout if and when this becomes an embarrassing thing for the politicians who have spoken up, and how to manage this. 

To sum: I’m not saying it was wrong to push for this level of broad awareness and consensus-building; I think it may well turn out to be necessary this early in order to navigate the challenges on the path to transformative AI, even if we still have decades until that point (and we may not). But there’s the potential for a serious downside/backlash that this community, and everyone who shares our concern about existential risk from AI, should be thinking carefully about, in terms of positioning for effectiveness on slightly longer timelines.

  
_Thank you to Shakeel Hashim, Shahar Avin, Haydn Belfield and Ben Garfinkel for feedback on a previous draft of this post._

reviews.thinking:
I'm analyzing this document through the lens of bias detection, looking for various cognitive, social, and methodological biases that might be present in the author's arguments about AI risk communication.

First, let me identify the main argument: The author suggests that current messaging about AI existential risks may be too urgent and could lead to a "crying wolf" scenario if the predicted short-timeline catastrophic outcomes don't materialize within the next decade. They argue for more nuanced communication that acknowledges longer potential timelines.

Potential biases I'm noticing:

1. **Hindsight Bias**: The author is preemptively concerned about how current warnings might look in retrospect if dangers don't materialize quickly. This is projecting a future hindsight bias onto the current situation.

2. **False Consensus Effect**: The author mentions their own longer timeline intuitions and suggests a "most likely" scenario without strong evidence, potentially overestimating how widely shared their view is.

3. **Availability Heuristic**: The comparison to "Limits to Growth" suggests the author is drawing on readily available examples of failed predictions, which might not be representative.

4. **In-group/Out-group Bias**: There's a subtle distinction made between the AI existential risk community and the AI ethics/FAccT communities, potentially creating an unnecessary division.

5. **Status Quo Bias**: The concern about "crying wolf" might reflect a bias toward maintaining credibility within existing power structures rather than focusing on the magnitude of potential risks.

6. **Optimism Bias**: The author's longer timeline intuitions could reflect an optimistic bias about how quickly AI capabilities might advance.

7. **Pessimism Bias**: Conversely, the concern about backlash might reflect a pessimistic view about how the public and policymakers process and remember warnings.

8. **Narrative Fallacy**: The author constructs a specific narrative about how events might unfold (the "crying wolf" scenario) that may oversimplify complex social and technological dynamics.

9. **Authority Bias**: The document references prominent AI scientists and CEOs as validation for the importance of the issue, potentially overweighting their opinions.

10. **Illusion of Control**: Some of the suggestions imply that careful messaging can significantly control how the AI risk narrative evolves, which might overestimate the community's influence.

The author does show awareness of some potential biases by acknowledging uncertainty, presenting alternative viewpoints, and recognizing the limitations of their own intuitions. They also include footnotes that provide counterarguments to their main concerns, which demonstrates some intellectual honesty.

Overall, while the document contains several potential biases, it also demonstrates self-awareness and attempts to mitigate some of them through careful qualifications and acknowledgment of alternative perspectives.
reviews.summary: The document contains several cognitive biases that affect its analysis of AI risk communication. Most notably, it exhibits narrative fallacy by constructing an oversimplified "crying wolf" scenario, false consensus effect by presenting personal timeline estimates as "most likely" without strong evidence, and in-group/out-group bias in its framing of AI safety versus ethics communities. The availability heuristic appears in comparisons to historical failed predictions like "Limits to Growth." However, the author also demonstrates awareness of uncertainty and includes counterarguments in footnotes, showing intellectual honesty that partially mitigates confirmation bias. The document would benefit from more explicit acknowledgment of these potential biases, greater precision in distinguishing between personal intuition and evidence-based claims, and more nuanced consideration of how public perception of technological risks actually evolves over time.

reviews.thinking:
I'm analyzing this document from a clarity and readability perspective, focusing on how effectively the author communicates their message about AI risk coverage.

**Readability Assessment:**
The document uses a mix of sentence lengths, which generally helps readability. However, there are several lengthy, complex sentences that could benefit from restructuring. The author employs a semi-formal tone appropriate for the EA Forum audience but includes some casual phrases like "that whole 2023 furore" which create tonal inconsistency.

The Flesch-Kincaid reading level appears to be around 11-12th grade, making it accessible to educated readers but potentially challenging for general audiences. This seems appropriate given the target audience of the EA Forum.

The document uses numbered sections (1, 2, 3) which helps organize the content, but the section titles could be more descriptive to better signal the content structure.

**Structural Coherence:**
The overall structure follows a logical progression: introduction → problem statement → potential scenario → recommendations. The author uses an epistemic status disclaimer upfront, which is helpful for context.

The document employs bullet points effectively in the recommendations section, improving scanability. However, the transitions between major sections could be smoother, and some paragraphs contain multiple ideas that could be separated for clarity.

The footnotes are appropriately used for supplementary information, though the placement of footnote markers within the text is sometimes awkward.

**Precision and Concision:**
There are instances of hedging language ("I think," "may," "possibly") which, while appropriate for expressing uncertainty, sometimes create wordiness. Some sentences contain redundancies or could be more concise.

The author uses specific examples and references to support their points, which strengthens precision. However, some concepts like "AI ethics/FAccT folk" are used without clear definition, potentially confusing readers unfamiliar with these terms.

**Audience Alignment:**
The document assumes significant prior knowledge about AI safety discussions, the EA community, and recent events in AI policy. This is likely appropriate for the EA Forum audience but creates accessibility barriers for newcomers.

The author references specific individuals (Geoff Hinton, Yann LeCun) and concepts without always providing sufficient context. Links to external resources are helpful but inconsistently formatted.

Overall, the document communicates its core message effectively to its intended audience but has several opportunities for clarity improvements.
reviews.summary: This document demonstrates moderate clarity with several strengths and opportunities for improvement. The author effectively uses structural elements like bullet points and section headings to organize complex ideas, and appropriately sets context with an epistemic status disclaimer. However, readability is hampered by several overly complex sentences, undefined technical terminology, and paragraphs containing multiple ideas without sufficient breaks. The document assumes significant background knowledge, creating potential accessibility barriers for readers new to the topic. The Flesch-Kincaid reading level (approximately 11-12th grade) is appropriate for the intended audience but could be challenging for general readers. Overall, while the core message is communicated effectively to the target audience, strategic sentence restructuring, more descriptive headings, and clearer definition of specialized terms would significantly enhance clarity and accessibility.
